original.text: Little give and go with JaeSung and Sonny. He flicks it over to DongKyung and he back flicks it into the back of the net.

paraphrases: JaeSung and Sonny played a quick one-two, then it was passed to DongKyung who flicked it right into the goal.
sentences.notes: flick over: (공을) 가볍게 툭 쳐서 넘기다. 축구 경기 해설에 사용됨.
sentences.translation: 이재성과 손흥민 사이에 짧은 패스 주고받기가 있었어요. 이재성이 이동경에게 살짝 넘겨줬고, 이동경은 뒤로 차 넣어 골망을 흔듭니다.

original.text: There's a lot of stuff (that) you guys do, that could potentially ruin your trip.

paraphrases: You might be doing a few things that could totally mess up your vacation.
Plenty of little habits can end up ruining your whole trip if you're not careful.
sentences.notes: ruin your trip: 여행을 망치다.
sentences.translation: 여러분들이 하는 많은 것들이 잠재적으로 여행을 망칠 수 있어요.

original.text: I'm not going to / won't let that happen. (no way, that's not happening)

paraphrases: I'm definitely making sure that doesn't happen.
No way I'm letting that go down.
sentences.notes: let that happen: 그런 일이 일어나도록 두다/허용하다.
sentences.translation: 저는 그렇게 되도록 두지 않을 거예요.

original.text: I'm going to talk you through the signs that your trip is going to end up being a disaster so you can course correct and end up having the best visit to London ever.

paraphrases: I'll point out the red flags so your trip doesn't turn into a total mess and you actually have a blast in London.
Let's walk through how to avoid a vacation disaster so you can have the best time ever.
sentences.notes: talk through: 자세히 설명하다, 처음부터 끝까지 논의하다. course correct: 방향을 수정하다.
sentences.translation: 저는 여러분의 여행이 결국 재앙으로 끝날 징후들을 처음부터 끝까지 설명해 드릴 거예요. 그래서 여러분이 방향을 수정하고 런던에서 최고의 방문을 할 수 있도록요.

original.text: I was willing to talk to anyone.

paraphrases: I was totally down to chat with whoever.
sentences.notes: willing to + 동사: 기꺼이 ~하다. open to + ~ing: ~에 개방적이다, ~할 의향이 있다.
sentences.translation: 저는 누구와도 기꺼이 이야기할 의향이 있었어요.

original.text: And we talked about feeling misunderstood, and that something was always off.

paraphrases: We talked about how it feels like no one gets us and how things just felt off.
sentences.notes: feel misunderstood: 오해받는다고 느끼다. off: 뭔가 이상한, 잘못된.
sentences.translation: 그리고 우리는 오해받는 기분과, 항상 뭔가 잘못 흘러간다는 것에 대해 이야기했어요. (오해받고, 항상 뭔가 잘못흘러가)

original.text: My friend told me she was convinced she had a sleeping disorder, but it turned out she was just diagnosed by TikTok.

paraphrases: My friend was so sure she had a sleep disorder, but it turns out she just got 'diagnosed' by a TikTok video.
She was convinced she couldn't sleep right, but she's really just listening to random TikToks.
sentences.notes: turn out: 결국 ~임이 드러나다, 알고 보니 ~이다. happen to v: 우연히도 ~하다, 혹시 ~에요?.
sentences.translation: 제 친구는 수면 장애가 있다고 확신했지만, 알고 보니 틱톡에 의해 진단받은 것이었어요.

original.text: It was just off of the pandemic and I had a family doctor, so I didn't really need to seek any outside help.

paraphrases: This was right after the pandemic, and since I had a regular doctor, I didn't need to look for any other help.
It was just as the pandemic was winding down, so I stuck with my family doctor instead of searching for anyone else.
sentences.notes: right off of: ~의 직후에. 'off of'는 'after' 또는 '~로부터'의 의미로 사용됨.
sentences.translation: 팬데믹이 막 끝난 직후였고 저는 주치의가 있었기 때문에 외부 도움을 구할 필요가 없었어요.

original.text: So it was very solitary.

paraphrases: It was a pretty lonely experience.
I was basically on my own throughout the whole thing.
sentences.notes: solitary: 혼자 하는, 고립된, 단독의.
sentences.translation: 그래서 그것은 매우 고립된 일이었어요.

original.text: Sorry, I couldn't help but overhear (you), but did you say you're looking for a good hairdresser?

paraphrases: Sorry, I couldn't help but hear what you were saying—did you mention you're looking for a good stylist?
I accidentally overheard you, but are you really in the market for a new hairdresser?
sentences.notes: couldn't help but overhear: 자신도 모르게 엿듣다. happen to overhear: 우연히 엿듣다.
sentences.translation: 죄송하지만, 저도 모르게(어쩔 수 없이) 엿듣게 되었는데, 좋은 미용사를 찾고 있다고 말씀하셨나요?

original.text: I know a great one.

paraphrases: I know a really good one.
I can recommend a great spot for that.
sentences.notes: great one: (앞서 언급된 명사를 대신하여) 훌륭한 사람/것.
sentences.translation: 제가 아주 좋은 분을 알아요.

original.text: I was just there, and I have some great recommendations for you.

paraphrases: I was just there, so I've got some solid recommendations for you.
I just visited that place and have some great tips if you need them.
sentences.notes: recommendation: 추천. (복수형으로 자주 사용됨)
sentences.translation: 제가 방금 거기 갔다 왔는데, 당신에게 줄 좋은 추천할 것들이 있어요.

original.text: The movie was interesting, to say the least.

paraphrases: The movie was interesting, to say the least.
Honestly, 'interesting' is putting it mildly.
sentences.notes: to say the least: 말할 것도 없이, 최소한으로 말해서. (주로 언급된 것보다 훨씬 더 심하다는 것을 강조할 때 사용)
sentences.translation: 그 영화는 최소한 흥미로웠어요.

original.text: The kids were playing in the park by themselves while their parents watched from a bench.

paraphrases: The kids were playing in the park on their own while their parents hung out on a bench.
Those kids were off playing by themselves while their parents watched from nearby.
sentences.notes: by oneself: 혼자서. on one's own: 혼자 힘으로, 독립적으로.
sentences.translation: 아이들은 부모가 벤치에서 지켜보는 동안 공원에서 자기들끼리 놀고 있었어요.

original.text: I'm so stressed out, I just want to get away from everything for a while.

paraphrases: I'm so burnt out; I just need to get away from everything for a bit.
I'm totally stressed and just want a break from it all.
sentences.notes: stressed out: 스트레스를 많이 받은. get away from: ~로부터 벗어나다.
sentences.translation: 너무 스트레스 받아요. 잠시 동안 모든 것으로부터 벗어나고 싶어요.

original.text: I felt completely out of place at the party because I didn't know anyone there.

paraphrases: I felt so awkward at the party since I didn't know a single soul.
I felt totally out of place there because I was a complete stranger to everyone.
sentences.notes: out of place: 제자리에 있지 않은, 어색한. in place with: ~와 잘 어울리다.
sentences.translation: 파티에서 아는 사람이 아무도 없어서 완전히 어색함을 느꼈어요.

original.text: This is the last time we're talking about this, right?

paraphrases: We're not talking about this anymore after today, okay?
This is the final time we discuss this, right?
sentences.translation: 이게 우리가 이것에 대해 이야기하는 마지막이죠, 그렇죠?

original.text: 'cause I don't want to have to remind you to clean your room every single day.

paraphrases: I'm tired of having to nag you about cleaning your room every single day.
I really don't want to keep telling you to tidy up your space day after day.
sentences.notes: remind: 상기시키다. get on one's case about: 잔소리하다. keep after someone: 계속 재촉하다.
sentences.translation: 왜냐면 매일 당신에게 방 청소를 하라고 상기시켜야 하는 상황이 싫으니까요.

original.text: I'll get a pint of sea salt, goat milk, and caramel, please.

paraphrases: I'd like a pint of sea salt, goat milk, and caramel, please.
Could I get a pint of sea salt, goat milk, and caramel?
sentences.notes: pint: 약 0.57리터(영국), 약 0.47리터(미국)의 액체 용량 단위. grab/get/take one: (상품을) 하나 집다/가져가다.
sentences.translation: 씨솔트, 고트밀크, 캐러멜 맛으로 1파인트 주세요.

original.text: My car could use a wash. It's all muddied up.

paraphrases: My car is covered in mud; it seriously needs a wash.
My car looks like a mess with all this mud, I should probably get it washed.
sentences.notes: could use: ~이 필요하다. all muddied up: 진흙으로 뒤덮인/엉망이 된. covered in mud: 진흙으로 덮인. messed up with mud: 진흙으로 엉망이 된.
sentences.translation: 제 차는 세차가 필요해요. 흙으로 완전히 엉망진창이에요.

original.text: I could really use a strong cup of coffee right now, I'm so sleepy.

paraphrases: I'm so tired, I really need a strong coffee right about now.
A strong cup of coffee would be amazing right now; I'm exhausted.
sentences.notes: could really use: ~이 필요하다. (강조)
sentences.translation: 지금 당장 진한 커피 한 잔이 정말 필요해요, 너무 졸려요.

original.text: I'm down for some pizza right now.

paraphrases: I'm totally up for pizza right now.
Pizza sounds great, I'm definitely in.
sentences.notes: down for: ~을 할 의향이 있는, ~에 동의하는 (Focus on agreement/joining)
sentences.translation: 지금 피자 좋아요. (피자 먹을 의향 있어요.)

original.text: I've got my alarm set for 7 a.m.

paraphrases: I set my alarm for 7 a.m.
I've got my alarm ready to go off at 7.
sentences.notes: set (something) for (time): (시간을) ~로 맞추다/정하다.
sentences.translation: 저는 알람을 아침 7시로 맞춰놨어요.

original.text: The alarm clock went off at 6 a.m., so I had to wake up.

paraphrases: My alarm started blaring at 6 a.m., so I had to drag myself out of bed.
The alarm went off at 6 this morning, which woke me up.
sentences.notes: go off: (알람, 폭탄 등이) 울리다, 터지다. set off: (경보기 등을) 울리게 하다.
sentences.translation: 알람 시계가 아침 6시에 울려서, 저는 일어나야 했어요.

original.text: I put it on for six.

paraphrases: I set it for six.
I've got it set to six.
sentences.notes: put on one's alarm: 알람을 맞추다. (구어체 표현)
sentences.translation: 저는 그것(알람)을 6시로 맞췄어요.

original.text: The power went out for an hour during the storm.

paraphrases: We lost power for about an hour during that storm.
The lights were out for an hour while it was storming.
sentences.notes: go out: (불, 전기가) 나가다, 꺼지다.
sentences.translation: 폭풍이 오는 동안 전기가 한 시간 동안 나갔어요.

original.text: Did you hear that Sarah and Tom are finally going out?

paraphrases: Have you heard that Sarah and Tom are finally a couple?
Did you catch the news that Sarah and Tom are dating now?
sentences.notes: go out: 사귀다. make a cute couple: 귀여운 커플이다.
sentences.translation: 사라와 톰이 드디어 사귄다는 소식 들었어?

original.text: You should probably throw out that milk; it smells like it's gone bad / spoiled.

paraphrases: You better toss that milk; it smells like it's gone bad.
That milk smells spoiled, you should probably just throw it away.
sentences.notes: throw out: 버리다. go bad/spoil: (음식이) 상하다.
sentences.translation: 그 우유는 아마 버려야 할 것 같아요. 상한 냄새가 나요.

original.text: She kept cutting me off every time I tried to speak.

paraphrases: She wouldn't stop interrupting me every time I opened my mouth.
Every time I tried to say something, she just cut me right off.
sentences.notes: cut off: (말을) 자르다, 중단시키다. cut in: 끼어들다, 방해하다.
sentences.translation: 제가 말하려고 할 때마다 그녀는 계속 제 말을 잘랐어요.

original.text: Even if the most important information is in the second part of the sentence-the part about the stranger cutting in-it's much more natural to set the scene/background first, then the event.

paraphrases: Even if the main point is in the second half of the sentence, it's usually better to set the scene first.
It feels more natural to give some context before jumping into the main event.
sentences.notes: set the scene: 배경/상황을 설정하다. 'was ~ing when' 패턴은 진행 중인 행동(배경) 중에 새로운 사건이 발생했음을 나타냅니다.
sentences.translation: 가장 중요한 정보가 문장의 두 번째 부분, 즉 낯선 사람이 끼어드는 부분에 있더라도, 상황/배경을 먼저 설정한 다음 사건을 설명하는 것이 훨씬 더 자연스럽습니다.

original.text: Ugh, I can't believe I just spilled my coffee all over my new shirt. I feel so dumb.

paraphrases: Oh man, I just got coffee all over my new shirt. I'm such a clutz.
Ugh, I'm so clumsy; I just spilled my coffee everywhere.
sentences.notes: spill: 쏟다. all over: 온통 ~에.
sentences.translation: 아, 내가 새 셔츠에 커피를 다 쏟았다니 믿을 수가 없어. 너무 바보 같아.

original.text: Oh, don't worry about it at all. If it makes you feel better, I walked out of my house this morning with my shirt on backward.

paraphrases: Seriously, don't even worry about it. If it helps, I left the house with my shirt on backward this morning.
No big deal! I actually walked out today with my shirt on the wrong way.
sentences.notes: don't worry about it at all: 전혀 걱정하지 마세요. make you feel better: 기분이 나아지게 하다. on backward / wear backward / put on backward: 뒤집어 입은 채로, 거꾸로 입다.
sentences.translation: 아, 전혀 걱정하지 마세요. 그게 당신 기분을 낫게 해준다면, 저는 오늘 아침에 셔츠를 뒤집어 입고 집을 나섰어요.

original.text: We went to the beach after you took me to that one beach, I kept going back.

paraphrases: We headed to the beach after you showed me that one spot; I've been going back ever since.
I kept visiting that beach after you took me there that first time.
sentences.notes: keep going back: 계속 돌아가다, 계속 방문하다. walk/drive around a bit: 좀 걸어/운전해 다니다. walk down the main strip: 중심 거리를 걸어 내려가다.
sentences.translation: 당신이 나를 그 해변에 데려다준 후에, 저는 계속 (그곳으로) 돌아갔어요.

original.text: I'm pretty full, so I'm going to pass on dessert tonight.

paraphrases: I'm stuffed, so I'll skip dessert tonight.
I think I'll pass on dessert; I'm way too full.
sentences.notes: pass on: ~을 사양하다, ~을 거절하다. (메시지 등을) 전달하다.
sentences.translation: 배가 꽤 불러서 오늘 밤 디저트는 사양할게요.

original.text: You can leave out the fresh herbs if you don't have any.

paraphrases: If you don't have any fresh herbs, feel free to just skip them.
It's fine to leave the herbs out if you're short on ingredients.
sentences.notes: leave out: ~을 빼다, 생략하다.
sentences.translation: 신선한 허브가 없다면 빼도 돼요.

original.text: We missed out on the early bird special at the restaurant because we were running late.

paraphrases: We were running late and missed the early bird special at the restaurant.
We missed the deal because we didn't get to the restaurant on time.
sentences.notes: miss out on: ~을 놓치다, ~에 참여하지 못하다.
sentences.translation: 늦어서 레스토랑의 얼리버드 스페셜을 놓쳤어요.

original.text: We had to wait until the fog cleared up / lifted to see the mountain view.

paraphrases: We couldn't see the mountains until the fog finally lifted.
We had to hang out and wait for the fog to clear before we could see the view.
sentences.notes: clear up / lift: (안개, 날씨 등이) 걷히다, 개다.
sentences.translation: 산의 풍경을 보기 위해 안개가 걷힐 때까지 기다려야 했어요.

original.text: The whole play was a little too serious for me, but the main character's super campy monologues saved it.

paraphrases: The play was a bit heavy for me, but the main character's hilarious, over-the-top monologues made it worth it.
It was a pretty serious play, but the lead's campy acting really saved the show.
sentences.notes: campy: 과장되고 우스꽝스러운, 연극적인. monologue: 독백.
sentences.translation: 연극 전체가 저에게는 좀 너무 진지했지만, 주연 배우의 매우 우스꽝스러운(과장되고 연극적인) 독백이 살렸어요.

original.text: The dessert is just so good. I'm going back for seconds / I'm getting seconds.

paraphrases: This dessert is amazing; I'm definitely going back for seconds.
I have to get a second helping because this is so delicious.
sentences.notes: go back for seconds / get seconds: (음식의) 두 번째 접시를 먹다, 두 그릇째 먹다.
sentences.translation: 이 디저트 정말 맛있네요. 한 접시 더 먹어야겠어요. (한접시 더해야것어)

original.text: I asked for a small portion of the pasta. Too much hurts my stomach.

paraphrases: I only wanted a small serving of pasta since too much makes me feel sick.
I went with a small portion because a big meal usually hurts my stomach.
sentences.notes: portion of: ~의 1인분. hurt one's stomach: 속을 아프게 하다.
sentences.translation: 파스타는 적은 양으로 달라고 했어요. 너무 많이 먹으면 속이 안 좋아.

original.text: The majority of the homes were built throughout the 70s and the 80s with the large lots.

paraphrases: Most of these houses were built in the 70s and 80s on pretty big lots.
The bulk of the homes here date back to the 70s and 80s and come with large yards.
sentences.notes: large lot: 넓은 부지. line with: ~으로 줄지어 있다. coupled/along with: ~와 더불어, ~에 곁들여. close proximity: 매우 가까움 (for emphasis). highly regarded as: ~로 높이 평가받는.
sentences.translation: 대부분의 주택은 70년대와 80년대에 걸쳐 넓은 부지와 함께 지어졌습니다.

original.text: I wouldn't say they are typical, but the fact that they happen at all is still a problem.

paraphrases: I wouldn't call it typical, but the fact it happens at all is still a concern.
It's not a common thing, but it's still weird that it happens.
sentences.notes: at all: (부정문/의문문/조건문에서) 조금이라도, 전혀. (강조)
sentences.translation: 그것들이 일반적이라고 말할 수는 없지만, 조금이라도 발생한다는 사실 자체가 여전히 문제입니다.

original.text: The new cafe is good, but I wouldn't (go so far as to) say it's the best in the city.

paraphrases: The new cafe is nice, but I wouldn't go as far as saying it's the absolute best.
It's a good spot, but calling it the best in the city might be a stretch.
sentences.notes: go so far as to say: ~라고까지 말하다. (자신이 생각하는 한계를 넘어서는 표현임을 나타냄)
sentences.translation: 새 카페는 좋지만, 시내에서 최고라고 할 정도까지(~라고할 정도까진) 말하지는 않겠어요.

original.text: I can't believe you went that far! Did you really tell your boss that he was wrong?

paraphrases: I can't believe you actually said that! Did you really call your boss out like that?
You really went there? Did you actually tell your boss he was flat-out wrong?
sentences.notes: go that far: 그렇게까지 하다. (주로 놀라움이나 과도함에 대한 반응을 나타냄)
sentences.translation: 네가 그렇게까지 했다니 믿을 수가 없어! 네 상사에게 그가 틀렸다고 정말 말했니?

original.text: That's why we focus (a lot of our attention in the work that we do) on helping employers understand how we can make those positive changes in those cultures.

paraphrases: That's why we put so much effort into helping bosses understand how to improve their workplace culture.
We're really focused on showing employers how to make positive changes in their companies.
sentences.notes: focus on + ~ing / 명사: ~에 집중하다.
sentences.translation: 그렇기 때문에 우리는 고용주들이 그러한 문화에서 어떻게 긍정적인 변화를 만들 수 있는지 이해하도록 돕는 데 (우리가 하는 일에서 많은 관심을) 집중합니다.

original.text: I find myself checking my phone a lot as I go through my day.

paraphrases: I constantly find myself looking at my phone throughout the day.
I've noticed I check my phone way too often as I'm going about my day.
sentences.notes: find oneself ~ing: 자신도 모르게 ~하고 있음을 알게 되다. as one goes through one's day: 하루를 보내는 동안.
sentences.translation: 하루를 보내는 동안 휴대폰을 많이 확인하는 제 자신을 발견해요.

original.text: You'll have plenty of time for this during your day.

paraphrases: You'll definitely have time to get this done during your day.
There's more than enough time for this in your daily schedule.
sentences.notes: plenty of time: 충분한 시간. during your day: 하루 일과 중에. throughout the day: 하루 종일, 온종일.
sentences.translation: 하루 일과 중에 이것을 할 충분한 시간이 있을 거예요.

original.text: (looking at the inside of the wall) This is plaster seeping/coming through, but you can see there's no signs of mold or anything like that.

paraphrases: That's just some plaster coming through, but at least there's no sign of mold.
You can see some plaster here, but thankfully it's not mold or anything like that.
sentences.notes: seep through / come through: 스며 나오다. plaster: 회벽, 석고. take down: 철거하다, 제거하다. like that: 그와 같은 것.
sentences.translation: 이것은 석회가 스며 나오거나 있는 것이지만, 곰팡이나 그와 같은 것의 징후는 없음을 볼 수 있습니다.

original.text: My dad's going to come over.

paraphrases: My dad's stopping by.
My dad is coming over to the house.
sentences.notes: come over: (집에) 방문하다, 오다. shout out to: ~에게 감사나 인사를 표하다. get something done: ~을 끝내다.
sentences.translation: 아빠가 오실 거예요.

original.text: But he's also going to help me with this 통창 (picture window) right here.

paraphrases: He's actually going to help me with this big window right here.
My dad's gonna help me out with this 통창.
sentences.notes: picture window: 전망용 대형 창문, 통창. take out: 제거하다. add/put in: 추가하다, 설치하다.
sentences.translation: 하지만 그는 또한 바로 여기 있는 이 큰 통창도 저를 도와줄 거예요.

original.text: Here's the wallpaper I ordered for the bathroom, it's floral with a dark background. I think with the white vanity it's going to look amazing.

paraphrases: Check out this wallpaper I got for the bathroom! It's floral with a dark background, which I think will look awesome with the vanity.
I think this floral wallpaper with the black backdrop will go perfectly with the claw-foot tub.
sentences.notes: backdrop/background: 배경. go well with / look nice with: ~와 잘 어울리다. claw foot tub: 발 달린 욕조. vanity: 화장대.
sentences.translation: 이것은 제가 욕실용으로 주문한 벽지입니다. 꽃무늬이고 검은색 배경을 가지고 있는데, 이것이 발 달린 욕조, 세면대와 잘 어울릴 것 같아요.

original.text: So I'll put all this up on all the walls but the ceiling.

paraphrases: I'm going to put this up on all the bathroom walls except for the ceiling.
I'll be hanging this wallpaper everywhere but the ceiling.
sentences.notes: put up all the way around / put up all over: ~의 전체에 걸쳐 설치하다/붙이다. aside from / except for: ~을 제외하고. put up / hang: (벽지, 그림 등을) 걸다, 붙이다, 설치하다.
sentences.translation: 그래서 천장을 제외하고 욕실 전체를 빙 둘러 이것을 붙일 거예요.

original.text: We can put you up for the night if the buses stop running.

paraphrases: If you miss the last bus, you can just crash at our place for the night.
You're welcome to stay over if the buses stop running.
sentences.notes: put someone up: ~에게 숙소를 제공하다, 재워주다.
sentences.translation: 막차를 놓치면 하룻밤 재워줄 수 있어요.

original.text: Now I can tell the subtle difference between 'I get it' and 'I got it.'

paraphrases: I'm starting to get the hang of the subtle difference between 'I get it' and 'I got it'.
I can finally see the difference now; I'm slowly figuring out when to use 'I get it' versus 'I got it'.
sentences.notes: get the hang of: ~의 요령을 터득하다, ~에 익숙해지다.
sentences.translation: 이제 알겠어요. 'I get it'과 'I got it' 사이의 미묘한 차이를 천천히 익히고 있어요.

original.text: Do you guys take old tires? Can you take the tire off of the rim and discard it for me?

paraphrases: Do you guys take old tires for disposal? Can you take the rubber off the rims and get rid of them for me?
I'm looking to dispose of some old tires; do you handle that?
sentences.notes: for disposal: 폐기 처리를 위해. remove from the rims: 휠에서 분리하다. at one's disposal: ~의 마음대로 사용할 수 있는.
sentences.translation: 폐기를 위해 헌 타이어를 받으시나요? 타이어를 휠에서 분리하고 타이어의 고무 부분만 폐기 처리해 주세요.

original.text: How much would it cost to switch out my wheel covers and discard the old tires?

paraphrases: What's the price for swapping out my wheel covers and disposing of the old tires?
How much do you charge to switch out the wheel covers and get rid of the tires?
sentences.notes: wheel cover: 휠 커버. swap out / swap/switch from A to B: 교체하다, A에서 B로 바꾸다. take off: 벗기다. put on: 끼우다, 장착하다.
sentences.translation: 휠 커버를 교체하고 헌 타이어를 폐기하는 데 비용이 얼마나 들까요?

original.text: Can you please check the battery and engine oil as well? It's been a while since I replaced them.

paraphrases: How much is a standard oil change here?
Then please take a look and replace them if necessary
sentences.notes: check the battery and engine oil: 배터리와 엔진 오일을 확인하다. replace: 교체하다. standard oil change: 일반적인 오일 교환. take a look: 살펴보다.
sentences.translation: 배터리와 엔진 오일도 확인해 주시겠어요? 교체한 지 꽤 되었어요.

original.text: I can't be bothered to get dressed and go out in the cold.

paraphrases: I really can't be bothered to get ready and head out into the cold.
I'm too lazy to get dressed and go out in this freezing weather.
sentences.notes: can't/couldn't be bothered to + 동사: ~할 마음이 생기지 않는다, ~하는 게 귀찮다.
sentences.translation: 옷을 입고 추위 속으로 나갈 엄두가 나지 않아요.

original.text: I'd rather he didn't know.

paraphrases: I'd rather you didn't bring up the salary issue.
sentences.notes: I'd rather + Someone + 과거 동사: (다른 사람의 행동에 대한) 바람/선호를 표현할 때 (My preference for Your action => past tense)
sentences.translation: 저는 그가 모르는 편이 더 좋아요.

original.text: The store was closed early today, which was a real letdown.

paraphrases: The store was closed when I got there, which was a total bummer.
It was such a letdown to find the store closed early today.
sentences.notes: letdown: 실망, 낙담. bummer: 실망스러운 일.
sentences.translation: 가게가 오늘 일찍 문을 닫아서 정말 실망스러웠어요.

original.text: I really let you down.

paraphrases: I really disappointed you.
I'm sorry I let you down; I know I should have done better.
sentences.notes: let someone down: ~를 실망시키다.
sentences.translation: 제가 정말 당신을 실망시켰어요.

original.text: The price was / came out to around 50 dollars.

paraphrases: The total came to about 50 bucks.
It ended up being around 50 dollars.
sentences.notes: come out to: ~로 나오다, ~이 되다. bucks: 달러 (비격식).
sentences.translation: 가격은 약 50달러였습니다.

original.text: It turns out (that) they already had a few other companies in mind.

paraphrases: Turns out they were already looking at a couple of other companies.
It seems they already had some other companies in mind from the start.
sentences.notes: turn out: ~임이 드러나다, 밝혀지다. have ~ in mind: ~을 염두에 두다.
sentences.translation: 알고 보니 그들은 이미 몇몇 다른 회사들을 염두에 두고 있었어요.

original.text: I was thinking (that) we could go to the movies tonight.

paraphrases: I thought maybe we could catch a movie tonight.
I was thinking of going to see a movie tonight; are you down?
sentences.notes: catch a movie: 영화를 보다. be down for: ~할 의향이 있다.
sentences.translation: 오늘 밤에 영화 보러 갈까 생각 중이었어요.

original.text: We were going to go hiking, but I didn't feel up to it after staying up so late last night.

paraphrases: Do you feel up to meeting for coffee later, or are you still recovering from the cold?
She isn't feeling up to the presentation today because she's got a nasty cold.
I'm not really up for going out tonight.
sentences.notes: feel up to + 명사/동명사: ~을 할 기분/힘이 되다, ~을 하고 싶다. (Focus on desire/energy). not really up for: ~할 마음이 내키지 않는.
sentences.translation: 하이킹을 가려고 했지만, 어젯밤에 너무 늦게까지 깨어 있었더니 그럴 기분이 아니었어요.

original.text: Look, with/between the lease being up soon and the rent going up, I really think it's time we start looking for a new place.

paraphrases: Since our lease is almost over and the rent's increasing, we should definitely look for a new spot.
With the lease ending and rent going up, I think we really need to find another apartment.
sentences.notes: lease being up: 임대 계약이 끝나다. rent going up: 월세가 오르다. look for a new place: 새 장소를 찾다.
sentences.translation: 봐요, 곧 임대 계약이 끝나고 월세도 오르니, 이제 새 집을 찾아봐야 할 때인 것 같아요.

original.text: It's so nice not to have to park my SUV on the road.

paraphrases: I'll be able to park it on this parking pad during the winter, so I won't have to worry about getting hit by the snowplow.
sentences.notes: not to have to: ~할 필요가 없다. parking pad: 주차 공간. won't have to worry about: ~에 대해 걱정할 필요가 없을 것이다.
sentences.translation: SUV를 길가에 주차할 필요가 없어서 정말 좋아요.

original.text: We have the frame (all) built out for this area right here.

paraphrases: So, now we're going to see if it fits up there good/well. (finish up, get it done)
sentences.notes: build out: ~을 만들다, 완성하다. fit up: (장소 등에) 장비를 갖추다, 맞추다.
sentences.translation: 우리는 바로 이 영역에 대한 프레임을 (모두) 완성했습니다.

original.text: My windshield washer fluid is running out too fast. It's going down too fast.

paraphrases: run out / go down: 바닥나다, 고갈되다.
sentences.notes: run out / go down: 바닥나다, 고갈되다.
sentences.translation: 제 앞 유리 와셔액이 너무 빨리 바닥나고 있어요.

original.text: I couldn't get in touch with her all day.

paraphrases: I wasn't able to reach her the entire day.
I tried reaching her all day but couldn't get ahold of her.
sentences.notes: get in touch with: ~와 연락하다. get ahold of: ~와 연락이 닿다.
sentences.translation: 하루 종일 그녀와 연락이 닿지 않았어요.

original.text: He was disappointed, but he quickly brushed the failure off and started preparing for the next competition.

paraphrases: She was able to brush his sarcastic remarks off without getting angry.
She just shrugged off the rumors about her.
I couldn't shake off the weird feeling I had about that house.
They just brushed the rumors off, so the gossip died down eventually.
It's just a small mistake; you need to brush it off and keep working.
sentences.notes: brush/shake off / shrug off: (걱정, 문제 등을) 떨쳐내다, 대수롭지 않게 여기다. die down: (소문, 감정 등이) 사그라지다.
sentences.translation: 그는 실망했지만, 재빨리 그 실패를 떨쳐내고 다음 대회를 준비하기 시작했어요.

original.text: Actually, everything went as planned.

paraphrases: Everything actually went according to plan.
Things turned out just as we planned.
sentences.notes: go as planned: 계획대로 진행되다. according to plan: 계획대로.
sentences.translation: 사실, 모든 것이 계획대로 진행되었어요.

original.text: Because the complaint is MLS defending, but as you just said, some could go in a top five league and still have success.

paraphrases: Wasn't he a golden boot winner in the Premier League?
So, it's not as if(though) he hasn't shown that he can score at the same kind of rate at other levels in other competitions and for other teams. (He has totally shown that) (~인건 아니야. 이중 부정)
sentences.notes: it's not as if(though) ~: ~인 것은 아니다. (반대를 강하게 부정하며 주장을 펼 때 사용)
sentences.translation: 왜냐하면 불만은 MLS 수비력에 있지만, 방금 당신이 말했듯이, 일부는 상위 5개 리그에 가서도 성공할 수 있기 때문이죠.

original.text: It's not as if we haven't been trying to fix the car. We've already taken it to three different mechanics.

paraphrases: We've been trying to get the car fixed; we've even seen three different mechanics.
It's not like we're ignoring the car; we've already taken it to three shops.
sentences.notes: it's not as if(though) ~: ~인 것은 아니다. (상황을 완화시키거나 반박할 때 사용)
sentences.translation: 우리가 차를 고치려고 노력하지 않은 건 아니에요. 이미 세 명의 다른 정비사에게 가져갔었어요.

original.text: Hey, chill out! The bus will be here in a minute.

paraphrases: Take it easy! The bus is gonna be here any second.
Just relax! We've only got a minute until the bus arrives.
sentences.notes: chill out: 진정하다, 긴장을 풀다.
sentences.translation: 야, 진정해! 버스 곧 올 거야.

original.text: We need someone who can hit the ground running.

paraphrases: We're looking for someone who can jump right in and get things done.
We need a person who can start contributing immediately without much training.
sentences.notes: hit the ground running: 즉시/시작부터 효과적으로 일하다. (새로운 직장이나 프로젝트에서)
sentences.translation: 우리는 즉시 효과적으로 일을 시작할 수 있는 사람이 필요해요.

original.text: I dropped off this morning for a tire change. I'm just calling to check on the progress.

paraphrases: I left my car for a tire change this morning; just wanted to see how it's coming along.
I'm just checking in on my car—it's in for tires. Is it ready yet?
sentences.notes: drop off: (물건/사람을) 내려주다, 맡기다. check on the progress: 진행 상황을 확인하다. expect to be ready: 준비가 완료될 것을 예상하다.
sentences.translation: 오늘 아침 타이어 교체를 위해 차를 맡겼어요. 진행 상황을 확인하려고 전화했습니다.

original.text: I just stopped by on my way.

paraphrases: I just popped in while I was passing by.
I was on my way home and decided to stop in for a bit.
sentences.notes: stop by: 잠깐 들르다. in the area: 이 근처에.
sentences.translation: 오는 길에 잠깐 들렀어요.

original.text: How's it coming (along)? Is it almost done?

paraphrases: How's the progress? Are you nearly finished?
How are things coming along? Is it about ready?
sentences.notes: How's it coming (along)?: (진행 상황을 물을 때) 어떻게 되어가요? (How's it going? 은 안부를 물을 때) How much longer will it be?: 얼마나 더 걸릴까요?
sentences.translation: 어떻게 돼가고 있어요? 거의 다 됐나요?

original.text: Can you scrape out the coconut meat for me? / Can you scoop out the flesh for me?

paraphrases: Could you scoop the coconut meat out for me?
Would you mind scraping the flesh out of this coconut?
sentences.notes: scrape out / scoop out: (내용물을) 긁어내다, 파내다. cut open: 베어 열다. get to the meat: 속살에 닿다/도달하다.
sentences.translation: 코코넛 속살을 좀 긁어/파내 줄 수 있나요? (코코넛 과육 좀 긁어줘)

original.text: When we went camping, we just ate off the pot we cooked the stew in.

paraphrases: During our camping trip, we just ate straight from the pot.
We didn't use plates while camping; we just ate out of the stew pot.
sentences.notes: eat off (something): ~에서 음식을 먹다. drive someone crazy: ~를 미치게 만들다, 짜증나게 하다.
sentences.translation: 캠핑 갔을 때, 우리는 스튜를 끓인 냄비에서 그냥 먹었어요.

original.text: I gotta go run to burn/work off all the pizza I ate last night.

paraphrases: I need a run to work off that pizza from last night.
I'm going for a run to burn off all those pizza calories.
sentences.notes: burn off / work off: (칼로리 등을) 운동으로 소모시키다.
sentences.translation: 어젯밤에 먹은 피자를 모두 소모시키기 위해 운동하러 가야 해요.

original.text: This hotel really spoiled me with their service. Nothing else seems good enough anymore.

paraphrases: The service here was so amazing that every other hotel feels like a step down now.
I've been totally spoiled by this hotel's service; nothing else compares anymore.
sentences.notes: spoil with: ~으로 (너무 잘해줘서) 버릇없게 만들다, 기준을 높이다. not seem good enough anymore: 더 이상 충분히 좋게 보이지 않다.
sentences.translation: 이 호텔 서비스가 저를 정말 버릇없게 만들었어요. 이제 다른 어떤 것도 충분히 좋게 보이지 않네요.

original.text: I get to travel for work, which is awesome.

paraphrases: I have the chance to travel for my job, and I love it.
Traveling for work is a great perk that I really enjoy.
sentences.notes: get to + 동사: ~할 기회/특권을 얻다. (긍정적 의미) have got to (gotta): ~해야 한다. (의무)
sentences.translation: 저는 일 때문에 여행할 기회/특권을 얻어요. 정말 멋지죠.

original.text: She was worried about presenting in English, but she absolutely pulled it off.

paraphrases: Even though she was nervous about the English presentation, she nailed it.
She was anxious about presenting in English, but she did a fantastic job in the end.
sentences.notes: pull off: (어려운 일을) 해내다, 성공시키다. (Focuses on difficulty, overcoming a challenge),  nail it: 완벽하게 해내다. get it done: 끝내다.
sentences.translation: 그녀는 영어로 발표하는 것에 대해 걱정했지만, 그것을 멋지게 해냈어요.

original.text: We need to pull off the highway at the next exit for gas.

paraphrases: We should take the next exit to get some gas.
Let's pull off the highway at the coming exit because we're running low on fuel.
sentences.notes: pull off: (도로 등에서) 벗어나다. at the next exit: 다음 출구에서. pull over: (차를) 길가에 대다. blow out: (타이어가) 터지다.
sentences.translation: 주유를 위해 다음 출구에서 고속도로를 빠져나가야 해요.

original.text: This type of thing used to throw me, but I'm older now, I don't let it get to me so much.

paraphrases: I used to get flustered by this kind of stuff, but now I just take it in stride.
That sort of thing used to bother me, but I've learned not to let it affect me anymore.
sentences.notes: throw (someone): ~를 당황하게 하다. let it get to me: ~때문에 속상해하다/신경 쓰다. don't take it seriously anymore: 더 이상 심각하게 받아들이지 않다.
sentences.translation: 이런 종류의 일은 예전에는 저를 당황하게 만들었지만, 이제 나이가 들어서 그것에 크게 신경 쓰지 않아요.

original.text: Do I make myself clear?

paraphrases: Do you understand what I'm saying?
Is my point clear to you?
sentences.notes: make oneself clear: 자신의 의사/뜻을 명확하게 하다. make intentions clear: 의도를 명확히 하다.
sentences.translation: 제 말이 명확한가요? (내 뜻이 분명한가요?)

original.text: How has your commute been lately?

paraphrases: How's the trip to work been recently?
How's the commute treating you these days?
sentences.notes: commute / travel to work / trip to the office: 통근, 출퇴근. drag on: 지루하게 계속되다.
sentences.translation: 요즘 출퇴근은 어땠어요?

original.text: I'm happy with our decision, but I want to leave the floor open in case anyone has any objections.

paraphrases: I'm good with what we decided, but feel free to speak up if you have any concerns.
I support this choice, but I'm still open to hearing other opinions.
sentences.notes: leave the floor open: 발언 기회를 주다, 토론의 여지를 남겨두다.
sentences.translation: 저는 우리의 결정에 만족하지만, 혹시 반대 의견이 있는 분이 있을까 봐 발언 기회를 열어두고 싶어요.

original.text: Her diamond necklace for the casual dinner party felt a little over the top.

paraphrases: It felt a bit excessive for her to wear a diamond necklace to such a casual dinner.
Wearing a diamond necklace to a casual party was definitely a bit much.
sentences.notes: over the top: 지나친, 과장된.
sentences.translation: 캐주얼한 저녁 식사 파티에 그녀의 다이아몬드 목걸이는 약간 지나쳤다고 느껴졌어요.

original.text: Only immediate family was present at the small, intimate wedding ceremony.

paraphrases: The wedding was very small, with only close family members attending.
Only the nearest relatives were there for the intimate ceremony.
sentences.notes: immediate family: 직계 가족. intimate: 친밀한,사적인,(분위기가) 아늑한.
sentences.translation: 작고 친밀한 결혼식에는 직계 가족만 참석했습니다.

original.text: So that's what was going on all along!

paraphrases: So that's what's been happening the whole time!
I finally see what was really going on right from the start.
sentences.notes: all along: 처음부터, 내내. what was going on: 무슨 일이 일어나고 있었는지.
sentences.translation: 그래서 내내 무슨 일이 일어나고 있었던 건지 알겠어요!

original.text: I accidentally bleached my faded jeans even more.

paraphrases: I ended up making my faded jeans even lighter by mistake with bleach.
I accidentally messed up my jeans by bleaching them more than I meant to.
sentences.notes: bleach: 표백하다. faded jeans: 물 빠진 청바지. distressed denim: 낡은 느낌을 준 데님. dark-wash jeans: 어두운 색 청바지.
sentences.translation: 실수로 물 빠진 청바지를 더 많이 표백했어요.

original.text: He changes into his overalls before he clocks in for his shift at the factory.

paraphrases: He puts on his work overalls before starting his factory shift.
Before he punches in for work, he swaps his clothes for factory overalls.
sentences.notes: overalls: 작업복, 멜빵바지. clocks in: 출근 시간을 기록하다.
sentences.translation: 그는 공장에서 교대 근무를 위해 출근하기 전에 작업복으로 갈아입어요.

original.text: I packed/put in/threw in five pairs of socks when I was packing.

paraphrases: I made sure to pack five pairs of socks.
I tossed five pairs of socks into my bag while I was getting ready.
sentences.notes: pack/put in/throw in: (짐을) 챙겨 넣다.
sentences.translation: 짐을 쌀 때 양말 다섯 켤레를 챙겨 넣었어요.

original.text: I need a new pair of glasses. - I gotta get new glasses.

paraphrases: I really need to get some new glasses.
I've got to find a new pair of glasses soon.
sentences.notes: I gotta get new glasses: 'I have got to get new glasses'의 구어체 축약형. (Very casual, dropping 'a pair of')
sentences.translation: 새 안경이 필요해요.

original.text: I tried to convince Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson to just give me the money they would've spent on my meal instead, because there was a lot I could do with that kind of cash.

paraphrases: I asked the Jeffersons if I could just have the cash for my meal, thinking I could put it to better use.
I tried to talk them into giving me the meal money because I really needed the extra cash.
sentences.notes: would've + p.p.: ~했을 것이다. (과거에 일어나지 않은 일에 대한 가정) could do with that kind of cash: 그 정도 현금으로 할 수 있는 일이 많다.
sentences.translation: 저는 제퍼슨 씨 부부에게 대신 제 식사비로 썼을 돈을 그냥 저에게 달라고 설득하려 했어요. 왜냐하면 그 정도 현금으로는 제가 할 수 있는 일이 많았기 때문이죠.

original.text: Honestly I just loved the opportunity to go down there and pitch myself, and get out of my comfort zone.

paraphrases: I actually enjoyed the chance to present myself and try something totally different.
It was great to challenge myself by going down there and showing what I can do.
sentences.notes: pitch oneself: 자신을 어필하다/홍보하다. get out of one's comfort zone: 안락한 영역을 벗어나다. make sense to: ~하는 것이 합리적이다.
sentences.translation: 솔직히 저는 그곳에 가서 저 자신을 어필하고, 안락한 영역을 벗어날 기회가 좋았어요.

original.text: I just started here. I wasn't really expecting to get the 30 million dollar listing.

paraphrases: I'm new here, so I didn't actually think I'd land the 30 million dollar listing.
I just joined the team, and getting such a huge listing wasn't really on my radar.
sentences.notes: expecting to get: ~을 얻기를 예상하다. ready to play: 준비가 되다, 참여할 준비가 되다. put one's best foot forward: 최선을 다하다, 좋은 인상을 주려 노력하다. come prepared: 준비된 상태로 오다.
sentences.translation: 저는 여기서 막 시작했어요. 3천만 달러짜리 매물을 따낼 것이라고는 정말 예상하지 못했어요.

original.text: He worked on that project for six months straight without a break. Did he get a promotion?

paraphrases: He put in six solid months on that project without stopping. Was he promoted for all that effort?
He worked non-stop on that for half a year; surely he got a promotion, right?
sentences.notes: straight: 연속으로, 끊임없이. Would you expect otherwise?: 당연히 그렇지 않겠어요? (긍정적 대답을 유도하는 반문)
sentences.translation: 그는 쉬지 않고 6개월 연속으로 그 프로젝트를 진행했어요. 승진했나요?

original.text: The new intern is eager to learn, but honestly, he needs a whole lot of supervision right now.

paraphrases: The new intern is really keen, but he definitely needs someone to keep a close eye on him.
He's enthusiastic, for sure, but he's going to need a ton of guidance for a while.
sentences.notes: eager to learn: 배우고자 열망하는. a whole lot of: 엄청나게 많은. supervision: 감독, 관리.
sentences.translation: 새 인턴은 배우고자 하는 열의가 있지만, 솔직히 말해서 지금은 엄청나게 많은 감독이 필요해요.

original.text: I was wearing heels all day, but I finally changed into some reasonable shoes for the walk home.

paraphrases: I spent the whole day in heels, so I was so glad to switch to some comfortable shoes for my commute back.
After a long day in heels, I finally put on some sensible shoes for the walk home.
sentences.notes: changed into: ~으로 갈아입다/갈아 신다. reasonable shoes: 적절한/편안한 신발.
sentences.translation: 하루 종일 하이힐을 신고 있었지만, 집에 걸어가기 위해 드디어 편한 신발로 갈아 신었어요.

original.text: I'm secure in my sense of style, so I dress the way I like without worrying about others' opinions.

paraphrases: I'm confident in what I wear, so I don't really care what other people think of my outfits.
I just dress how I want because I'm happy with my own style and don't need anyone's approval.
sentences.notes: secure in: ~에 확신하는/자신 있는. feel insecure: 불안정하다고 느끼다.
sentences.translation: 저는 제 스타일에 자신감이 있어서, 다른 사람들의 의견을 걱정하지 않고 제가 좋아하는 방식으로 옷을 입어요.

original.text: He's really nervous about the presentation, but he's trying to put on a front that he's totally confident.

paraphrases: He's actually terrified of the presentation, but he's faking confidence pretty well.
He's putting on a brave face, even though he's super nervous about presenting.
sentences.notes: put on a front: 겉으로만 ~인 척하다, 허세를 부리다. totally confident: 완전히 확신하는.
sentences.translation: 그는 발표에 대해 정말 긴장하고 있지만, 완전히 자신감 있는 척 가장하려고 노력하고 있어요.

original.text: In Mount Druitt, there are a lot of social issues. There's a lot of cyclical poverty.

paraphrases: Mount Druitt deals with quite a few social problems, including generational poverty.
There's a recurring cycle of poverty and other social issues in the Mount Druitt area.
sentences.notes: cyclical poverty: 대물림되는 빈곤. generational welfare dependence: 세대 간 복지 의존. manifest in: ~에서 나타나다. big behaviours: 큰 문제 행동. whole variety of reasons: 아주 다양한 이유.
sentences.translation: 마운트 드루이트에는 많은 사회 문제가 있습니다. 순환적인 빈곤이 많습니다.

original.text: I had no friggin clue, zero clue on how to handle any of the behaviours already that were happening in this classroom, let alone a student with these complex needs.

paraphrases: I had absolutely no idea how to deal with the classroom behavior as it was, so a student with these needs was completely overwhelming.
I was totally lost with the existing classroom dynamic, never mind trying to support a student with such complex requirements.
sentences.notes: no friggin clue / zero clue: 전혀 모르다, 단서가 없다. let alone: ~은 물론이고, 하물며 ~은. (뒤에 오는 것이 더욱 불가능함을 강조)
sentences.translation: 저는 이미 이 교실에서 일어나고 있던 어떤 행동도 어떻게 다룰지 정말 아무런 단서도, 0의 단서도 없었는데, 하물며 이런 복잡한 요구를 가진 학생은 더더욱이요.

original.text: Being generous comes back to you.

paraphrases: If you're generous to others, it'll eventually pay off for you too.
Kindness has a way of returning to you in the end.
sentences.notes: being generous: 관대함. comes back to you: (한 행동의 결과가) 자신에게 되돌아오다.
sentences.translation: 관대하게 행동하는 것은 당신에게 되돌아옵니다.

original.text: Actually, we went to a farmer's market a few weekends ago and just parked nearby, and we got sideswiped.

paraphrases: We actually visited a farmer's market recently and someone hit the side of our parked car.
While we were at the farmer's market, our car got sideswiped by another driver nearby.
sentences.notes: farmer's market: 농산물 직거래 장터. get sideswiped / swipe the side of our car: (차가) 측면 충돌을 당하다.
sentences.translation: 사실 몇 주 전에 파머스 마켓에 갔다가 근처에 주차했는데, 저희 차가 측면 충돌을 당했어요.

original.text: He's going to be so bummed when he finds out they finished the pizza without him.

paraphrases: He'll be really disappointed when he hears they ate all the pizza before he got there.
It's gonna be a total bummer for him to find out the pizza's gone already.
sentences.notes: bummed / bummed out / super bummed: 실망한, 기분이 안 좋은.
sentences.translation: 자기를 빼고 피자를 다 먹어버린 것을 알게 되면 그는 매우 실망할 거예요.

original.text: I'm really happy this happened for her.

paraphrases: I'm so glad things worked out this way for her.
It's great to see her getting such a good opportunity finally.
sentences.notes: happen for someone: ~에게 좋은 일이 생기다. fresh start: 새로운 시작.
sentences.translation: 그녀에게 이런 일이 생겨서 정말 기뻐요.

original.text: Even after the controversial verdict, the defendant exhibited dignity and thanked the court for its time.

paraphrases: Despite the questionable verdict, the person on trial stayed composed and polite to the court.
The defendant showed a lot of class by thanking the judge after such a controversial ruling.
sentences.notes: controversial verdict: 논란이 많은 평결. exhibited dignity: 품위를 보여주었다. throughout: ~내내. focusing on ~ rather than: ~에 집중하며.
sentences.translation: 논란이 많은 평결 후에도 피고는 품위를 보여주었고 법원에 시간을 내어준 것에 감사했습니다.

original.text: I grew up in the country/city, in Canada.

paraphrases: My childhood was spent in the Canadian countryside/city.
I was raised in Canada, specifically in a rural/urban area.
sentences.notes: grow up in the country/city: 시골/도시에서 자라다.
sentences.translation: 저는 캐나다의 시골/도시에서 자랐어요.

original.text: If you're a prospective buyer, you got a couple kids, want to turn it into your family compound.

paraphrases: If you're looking to buy and have a family, you might want to consider making this into a larger family estate.
Potential buyers with children might see this place as the perfect spot for a multi-generational home.
sentences.notes: prospective buyer: 장래의 구매자. turn into: ~으로 바꾸다. family compound: 가족 거주지/집단 거주지. dissuade from: ~하는 것을 단념시키다. prospective costs: 예상 비용.
sentences.translation: 만약 당신이 장래의 구매자이고, 아이들이 있고, 이것을 당신의 가족 거주지로 바꾸고 싶다면.

original.text: Yeah, I think, not even for just a family but for anyone, it's the lack of privacy happening.

paraphrases: The main issue for anyone, not just families, is really the lack of privacy here.
I think the biggest drawback for anyone would be how little privacy they'd have.
sentences.notes: lack of privacy: 사생활 부족.
sentences.translation: 네, 가족뿐만 아니라 누구에게든, 일어나고 있는 사생활 부족 문제라고 생각해요.

original.text: There's something I'll put on your plate, important to me and this property.

paraphrases: I have a specific task for you that's really key for this property and for me personally.
I'm going to give you a responsibility that matters a lot for this project.
sentences.notes: put on your plate: ~에게 (책임지고 처리할) 일을 맡기다. nothing on my plate: 할 일이 없다. remedy through landscaping: 조경을 통해 해결하다. put someone in charge: ~에게 책임을 맡기다. block: 가리다, 차단하다.
sentences.translation: 제가 당신에게 맡길 일이 하나 있는데, 저와 이 부동산에 중요합니다.

original.text: The landscaping here is particularly important.

paraphrases: The yard work and plants are really crucial for this place.
This property's landscaping needs extra attention because it's so important.
sentences.notes: particularly important: 특히 중요한. in particular: 특히.
sentences.translation: 여기 조경은 특히 중요합니다.

original.text: I'm gonna show you downstairs. Don't trip on this wire. Watch your head here.

paraphrases: Let's go downstairs; just be careful of that wire and your head.
I'll show you the lower level now—watch your step and mind your head.
sentences.notes: trip on: ~에 걸려 넘어지다. Watch your head: 머리 조심하세요.
sentences.translation: 아래층을 보여드릴게요. 이 전선에 걸려 넘어지지 않도록 조심하세요. 여기 머리 조심하세요.

original.text: Now, all I need is for my phone to be dead when I finally find it.

paraphrases: Wouldn't it be just my luck if my phone is dead by the time I find it?
I bet my phone's going to be out of battery once it finally turns up.
sentences.notes: All I need is for [something bad] to happen: (비꼬는 표현) 안 좋은 일이 일어나면 완벽하겠다.
sentences.translation: 이제 폰만 방전되어 있으면 딱이네.

original.text: I can't imagine what you must be going through right now, but please know that I'm here for you.

paraphrases: I can only imagine how tough things are for you, but I'm here if you need anything.
Knowing how hard this must be for you, just remember that I've got your back.
sentences.notes: go through: (어려운 일을) 겪다, 경험하다.
sentences.translation: 지금 당신이 겪고 있을 일을 상상조차 할 수 없지만, 제가 당신 곁에 있다는 것을 알아주세요.

original.text: I hope things look up for you soon.

paraphrases: I really hope things start getting better for you soon.
Fingers crossed that everything turns around for you shortly.
sentences.notes: look up: (상황이) 나아지다, 호전되다.
sentences.translation: 상황이 곧 나아지기를 바라요.

original.text: I'm sure things will work out in the end.

paraphrases: I'm positive everything will turn out okay eventually.
Don't worry, I'm sure it'll all come together in the end.
sentences.notes: work out: (문제가) 해결되다, 잘 풀리다.
sentences.translation: 결국에는 모든 일이 잘 해결될 거라고 확신해요.

original.text: The project was complex and time-consuming, but the end result was worth it.

paraphrases: It was a difficult and long project, but seeing the final outcome made it all worth it.
Even though it took forever and was complicated, the finished product looks amazing.
sentences.notes: end result: 최종 결과. worth it: 가치가 있는.
sentences.translation: 그 프로젝트는 복잡하고 시간이 많이 걸렸지만, 최종 결과는 그만한 가치가 있었어요.

original.text: He offered to pay for my coffee, which was a very nice gesture.

paraphrases: He paid for my coffee, and I thought that was really sweet of him.
It was a kind gesture for him to pick up the tab for my coffee.
sentences.notes: nice gesture: 좋은 몸짓/호의.
sentences.translation: 그는 내 커피값을 내주겠다고 제안했는데, 그것은 매우 친절한 호의였어요.

original.text: The store was out of stock, so I had to go to another branch.

paraphrases: They didn't have what I needed in stock, so I tried a different location.
Since it was sold out there, I had to head to another store nearby.
sentences.notes: out of stock: 품절된, 재고가 없는.
sentences.translation: 그 가게는 재고가 없어서 다른 지점에 가야 했어요.

original.text: I'm still looking for a place to live, but I haven't found anything suitable yet.

paraphrases: I'm apartment hunting but haven't seen any good options yet.
I'm still searching for a spot, but nothing's quite right so far.
sentences.notes: suitable: 적절한, 알맞은.
sentences.translation: 여전히 살 곳을 찾고 있지만, 아직 적당한 곳을 찾지 못했어요.

original.text: The movie was so-so, not as good as I expected.

paraphrases: The movie was just okay; I was hoping for something better.
It was a pretty mediocre film, honestly—it didn't really live up to the hype.
sentences.notes: so-so: 그저 그런.
sentences.translation: 영화는 그저 그랬어요, 기대했던 것만큼 좋지 않았어요.

original.text: It's been a long day, I'm ready to hit the sack.

paraphrases: I've had such a long day; I'm definitely ready for bed.
It's been exhausting, matches and all—I think it's time for me to go to sleep.
sentences.notes: hit the sack: 잠자리에 들다.
sentences.translation: 긴 하루였어요, 이제 자러 가고 싶네요.

original.text: The meeting dragged on for three hours.

paraphrases: That meeting just wouldn't end; it lasted for three whole hours.
The discussion went on way too long—we were stuck there for three hours.
sentences.notes: drag on: 지루하게 계속되다.
sentences.translation: 회의가 3시간 동안 지루하게 계속되었어요.

original.text: The manager is tight with the owner, so be careful what you say around him.

paraphrases: The manager and the owner are pretty close, so mind your words when he's nearby.
Since the manager's tight with the boss, you should probably watch what you say.
sentences.notes: tight with: ~와 친한. be careful what you say around him: 그 주변에서 말조심하다.
sentences.translation: 매니저가 사장과 친하니, 그 주변에서는 말조심하세요.

original.text: I haven't been applying myself enough to my fitness goals lately, so I need to step it up.

paraphrases: I've been a bit lazy with my workouts lately, so I really need to put in more effort.
I need to step up my fitness game because I haven't been very focused on my goals recently.
sentences.notes: apply oneself to: ~에 전념하다, 집중하다. step up: (노력 등을) 높이다, 강화하다.
sentences.translation: 요즘 운동 목표에 충분히 전념/집중하지 못하고 있어서, 더 열심히 해야 해요.

original.text: I can't stand waiting in long lines at the grocery store on the weekends.

paraphrases: I absolutely hate standing in those long grocery store lines during the weekend.
Waiting in line forever at the store on weekends is something I just can't stand.
sentences.notes: can't stand: ~을 참을 수 없다, 몹시 싫어하다.
sentences.translation: 주말에 식료품점에서 긴 줄을 서서 기다리는 것을 참을 수 없어요.

original.text: They should be landing at the airport right about now.

paraphrases: I bet their flight is touching down right at this moment.
They should be arriving at the airport right about now.
sentences.notes: right about now: 지금쯤. (시간을 추측하여 말할 때)
sentences.translation: 그들은 지금쯤 공항에 착륙하고 있을 거예요.

original.text: I can't put my finger on it, but something feels different.

paraphrases: I can't quite identify what it is, but there's definitely a change.
Something's off, but I can't really explain exactly what it is.
sentences.notes: can't put one's finger on: 무엇인지 확실히 집어내지 못하다.
sentences.translation: 딱 꼬집어서 말할 수는 없지만, 뭔가 다른 느낌이에요.

original.text: I'm still looking for a place to live, but I haven't found anything suitable yet.

paraphrases: I'm apartment hunting but haven't seen any good options yet.
I'm still searching for a spot, but nothing's quite right so far.
sentences.notes: suitable: 적절한, 알맞은.
sentences.translation: 여전히 살 곳을 찾고 있지만, 아직 적당한 곳을 찾지 못했어요.

original.text: The movie was so-so, not as good as I expected.

paraphrases: The movie was just okay; I was hoping for something better.
It was a pretty mediocre film, honestly—it didn't really live up to the hype.
sentences.notes: so-so: 그저 그런.
sentences.translation: 영화는 그저 그랬어요, 기대했던 것만큼 좋지 않았어요.

original.text: It's been a long day, I'm ready to hit the sack.

paraphrases: I've had such a long day; I'm definitely ready for bed.
It's been exhausting—I think it's time for me to go to sleep.
sentences.notes: hit the sack: 잠자리에 들다.
sentences.translation: 긴 하루였어요, 이제 자러 가고 싶네요.

original.text: The meeting dragged on for three hours.

paraphrases: That meeting just wouldn't end; it lasted for three whole hours.
The discussion went on way too long—we were stuck there for three hours.
sentences.notes: drag on: 지루하게 계속되다.
sentences.translation: 회의가 3시간 동안 지루하게 계속되었어요.

original.text: I'm tied up at the moment, can I call you back?

paraphrases: I'm pretty busy right now; is it okay if I give you a call later?
Something's come up and I'm a bit swamped—can we talk in a bit?
sentences.notes: tied up: 매우 바쁜, 꼼짝 못 하는.
sentences.translation: 지금은 좀 바빠서, 제가 나중에 다시 전화해도 될까요?

original.text: I have a lot on my plate right now.

paraphrases: I'm juggling quite a few things at the moment.
I've got a ton of stuff to deal with right now; I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed.
sentences.notes: have a lot on one's plate: 해야 할 일이 매우 많다.
sentences.translation: 지금 해야 할 일이 너무 많아요.

original.text: It's been a while since we caught up.

paraphrases: We haven't talked in forever; we should definitely catch up soon.
It's been ages since we've really sat down and had a good chat.
sentences.notes: catch up: 밀린 이야기를 나누다.
sentences.translation: 우리가 밀린 이야기를 나눈 지 꽤 되었네요.

original.text: I'm looking forward to the weekend.

paraphrases: I can't wait for the weekend to get here.
I'm really excited for the weekend finally.
sentences.notes: looking forward to: ~을 고대하다/기다리다.
sentences.translation: 주말이 정말 기다려져요.

original.text: The food far exceeded my expectations.

paraphrases: The meal was even better than I thought it would be.
The food was absolutely amazing—it totally blew past what I was expecting.
sentences.notes: exceed one's expectations: 기대를 뛰어넘다.
sentences.translation: 음식이 제 기대를 훨씬 뛰어넘었어요.

original.text: I'm trying to cut back on sugar.

paraphrases: I'm attempting to eat less sugar these days.
I've been trying to reduce my sugar intake lately.
sentences.notes: cut back on: ~을 줄이다.
sentences.translation: 설탕을 줄이려고 노력 중이에요.

original.text: It's better to be safe than sorry.

paraphrases: It's wiser to be cautious now than to regret it later.
I'd rather take the extra step to be safe than take a risk and be sorry.
sentences.notes: better safe than sorry: 나중에 후회하는 것보다 조심하는 것이 낫다.
sentences.translation: 나중에 후회하는 것보다 조심하는 것이 나아요.
